citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 5-year old female Shiba-Inu dog, identified #9220, is observed with non-weight bearing lameness of its left forelimb.
The licensee reports that lameness has been slowly improving since first observed a few weeks ago, and the dog appears
to intermittently place its foot to the ground more often than observed by the inspector at the previous inspection, but that
veterinary care had not been sought until the morning of the current inspection. At that time, the phone was inoperable
and the licensee was unable to make contact with a veterinarian. Despite mild improvement, lameness of the current
nature is still a sign of significant pain and failure to seek care in a timely manner or establishing guidance to address
these issues may result in unnecessarily prolonged pain. The facility must assure the dog is seen by a veterinarian and,
going forward, must continue to maintain appropriate methods for diagnosing and treating medical problems.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A 5-year old female Shiba-Inu dog, identified #9220, is observed with non-weight bearing lameness of its left forelimb. 
The licensee reports that lameness has been slowly improving since first observed a few weeks ago, and the dog appears 
to intermittently place its foot to the ground more often than observed by the inspector at the previous inspection, but that 
veterinary care had not been sought until the morning of the current inspection. At that time, the phone was inoperable 
and the licensee was unable to make contact with a veterinarian. Despite mild improvement, lameness of the current 
nature is still a sign of significant pain and failure to seek care in a timely manner or establishing guidance to address 
these issues may result in unnecessarily prolonged pain. The facility must assure the dog is seen by a veterinarian and, 
going forward, must continue to maintain appropriate methods for diagnosing and treating medical problems. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
